title: BP-SGCN: Behavioral Pseudo-Label Informed Sparse Graph Convolution Network for Pedestrian and Heterogeneous Trajectory Prediction
author: Ruochen Li (Durham University), Stamos Katsigianni (Durham University), Tae-Kyun Kim (KAIST), Hubert P. H. Shum (Durham University)
background: The task involves predicting the future trajectories of various types of traffic agents, including pedestrians and vehicles, by modeling their movement behaviors based on past trajectory data.
contribution: This paper introduces a framework utilizing behavioral pseudo-labels to enhance trajectory prediction accuracy, achieving significant improvements over existing models.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often relied on annotated class labels for agents, which are costly and sometimes inadequate for capturing varied behaviors within a class.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by using machine-learned behavioral pseudo-labels, which are derived from motion features, to address intra-class behavior variations without requiring additional annotations.

key_innovation: The framework integrates a deep unsupervised clustering approach to learn pseudo-labels and a goal-guided prediction model, allowing for end-to-end optimization.
real_world_impact: By enhancing trajectory prediction capabilities, this research can contribute to safer autonomous driving and effective urban planning through improved understanding of agent interactions.
limitations: The paper does not mention any specific limitations.

new_terms.behavioral pseudo-labels: **Behavioral pseudo-labels** are machine-learned labels that categorize agents based on their observed motion dynamics, facilitating better trajectory prediction.
